Greatest common divisor of a finite set

type:
{α : Type u_1} →
  {β : Type u_2} → [inst : CancelCommMonoidWithZero α] → [inst : NormalizedGCDMonoid α] → Finset β → (β → α) → α
name: Finset.gcd
docString: Greatest common divisor of a finite set

If the greatest common divisor of each element and a natural number `x` in a finite set is 1, then the greatest common divisor of their product and `x` is also 1.

type: ∀ {ι : Type u_1} {t : Finset ι} {s : ι → ℕ} {x : ℕ}, (∀ i ∈ t, (s i).Coprime x) → (t.prod fun i => s i).Coprime x
name: Nat.Coprime.prod_left
docString: If the greatest common divisor of each element and a natural number `x` in a finite set is 1, then the greatest common divisor of their product and `x` is also 1.

This theorem states that for any two nonzero integers `a` and `b`, the greatest common divisor (gcd) of `a` and `b` is the smallest positive natural number that can be expressed as `a * x + b * y` for some integers `x` and `y`. In other words, the gcd of `a` and `b` is the least positive element of the set of all natural numbers `n` such that `n` can be written as a linear combination of `a` and `b` with integer coefficients.

type: ∀ {a b : ℤ}, a ≠ 0 → IsLeast {n | 0 < n ∧ ∃ x y, ↑n = a * x + b * y} (a.gcd b)
name: Int.gcd_least_linear
docString: This theorem states that for any two nonzero integers `a` and `b`, the greatest common divisor (gcd) of `a` and `b` is the smallest positive natural number that can be expressed as `a * x + b * y` for some integers `x` and `y`. In other words, the gcd of `a` and `b` is the least positive element of the set of all natural numbers `n` such that `n` can be written as a linear combination of `a` and `b` with integer coefficients.

Greatest common divisor of a multiset

type: {α : Type u_1} → [inst : CancelCommMonoidWithZero α] → [inst : NormalizedGCDMonoid α] → Multiset α → α
name: Multiset.gcd
docString: Greatest common divisor of a multiset

In a Euclidean domain with decidable equality, the greatest common divisor of any two elements divides the first element.

type: ∀ {R : Type u} [inst : EuclideanDomain R] [inst_1 : DecidableEq R] (a b : R), EuclideanDomain.gcd a b ∣ a
name: EuclideanDomain.gcd_dvd_left
docString: In a Euclidean domain with decidable equality, the greatest common divisor of any two elements divides the first element.

This theorem states that for any two integers `a` and `b`, the greatest common divisor (GCD) of `a` and `b` (calculated as a nonnegative integer) is a divisor of `b`. In other words, `b` is a multiple of the GCD of `a` and `b`. Here, `∣` is the "divides" relation in integer arithmetic, so `↑(Int.gcd a b) ∣ b` means that `b` divided by the GCD of `a` and `b` yields an integer.

type: ∀ {a b : ℤ}, ↑(a.gcd b) ∣ b
name: Int.gcd_dvd_right
docString: This theorem states that for any two integers `a` and `b`, the greatest common divisor (GCD) of `a` and `b` (calculated as a nonnegative integer) is a divisor of `b`. In other words, `b` is a multiple of the GCD of `a` and `b`. Here, `∣` is the "divides" relation in integer arithmetic, so `↑(Int.gcd a b) ∣ b` means that `b` divided by the GCD of `a` and `b` yields an integer.

The greatest common divisor (gcd) of two positive natural numbers,
viewed as positive natural number.

name: PNat.gcd
docString:
The greatest common divisor (gcd) of two positive natural numbers,
viewed as positive natural number.

The greatest common divisor between two elements.

type: {α : Type u_2} → [inst : CancelCommMonoidWithZero α] → [self : GCDMonoid α] → α → α → α
name: GCDMonoid.gcd
docString: The greatest common divisor between two elements.

If `ξ` is an integer, all its convergents equal `ξ`.

type: ∀ {ξ : ℤ} (n : ℕ), Real.convergent (↑ξ) n = ↑ξ
name: Real.convergent_of_int
docString: If `ξ` is an integer, all its convergents equal `ξ`.

Nonzero divisors have valuation greater than zero.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] [inst_2 : IsDedekindDomain R]
  (v : IsDedekindDomain.HeightOneSpectrum R) (x : ↥(nonZeroDivisors R)),
  0 < IsDedekindDomain.HeightOneSpectrum.intValuationDef v ↑x
name: IsDedekindDomain.HeightOneSpectrum.int_valuation_zero_le
docString: Nonzero divisors have valuation greater than zero.

If an integer with larger absolute value divides an integer, it is
zero.

type: ∀ {a b : ℤ}, a ∣ b → Int.natAbs b < Int.natAbs a → b = 0
name: Int.eq_zero_of_dvd_of_natAbs_lt_natAbs
docString:
If an integer with larger absolute value divides an integer, it is
zero.

The GCD is a divisor of the first element.

type: ∀ {α : Type u_2} [inst : CancelCommMonoidWithZero α] [self : GCDMonoid α] (a b : α), gcd a b ∣ a
name: GCDMonoid.gcd_dvd_left
docString: The GCD is a divisor of the first element.

The divisors of a product of natural numbers are the pointwise product of the divisors of the
factors.

type: ∀ (m n : ℕ), Nat.divisors (m * n) = Nat.divisors m * Nat.divisors n
name: Nat.divisors_mul
docString:
The divisors of a product of natural numbers are the pointwise product of the divisors of the
factors.

`⊤` is the greatest element

type: ∀ {α : Type u} [self : BooleanAlgebra α] (a : α), a ≤ ⊤
name: BooleanAlgebra.le_top
docString: `⊤` is the greatest element

`A[x]` is a fractional ideal for every integral `x`.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing R] (S : Submonoid R) {P : Type u_2} [inst_1 : CommRing P] [inst_2 : Algebra R P]
  [loc : IsLocalization S P] (x : P), IsIntegral R x → IsFractional S (Subalgebra.toSubmodule (Algebra.adjoin R {x}))
name: FractionalIdeal.isFractional_adjoin_integral
docString: `A[x]` is a fractional ideal for every integral `x`.

The integers modulo `n : ℕ`.

type: ℕ → Type
name: ZMod
docString: The integers modulo `n : ℕ`.

For nonzero integers `a` and `b`, `gcd a b` is the smallest positive natural number that can be
written in the form `a * x + b * y` for some pair of integers `x` and `y`

type: ∀ {a b : ℤ}, a ≠ 0 → IsLeast {n | 0 < n ∧ ∃ x y, ↑n = a * x + b * y} (Int.gcd a b)
name: Int.gcd_least_linear
docString:
For nonzero integers `a` and `b`, `gcd a b` is the smallest positive natural number that can be
written in the form `a * x + b * y` for some pair of integers `x` and `y`

If `(x, y)` is a solution with `x` positive, then all its powers have positive `x`.

type: ∀ {d : ℤ} {a : Pell.Solution₁ d}, 0 < Pell.Solution₁.x a → ∀ (n : ℤ), 0 < Pell.Solution₁.x (a ^ n)
name: Pell.Solution₁.x_zpow_pos
docString: If `(x, y)` is a solution with `x` positive, then all its powers have positive `x`.

The floor of a rational number `a` is the largest integer less than or equal to `a`.

type: ℚ → ℤ
name: Rat.floor
docString: The floor of a rational number `a` is the largest integer less than or equal to `a`.

Multiplication by positive integers is injective

type: ∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : Semiring R] [self : BinomialRing R] (n : ℕ), n ≠ 0 → Function.Injective fun x => n • x
name: BinomialRing.nsmul_right_injective
docString: Multiplication by positive integers is injective

A fundamental solution has positive `x`.

type: ∀ {d : ℤ} {a : Pell.Solution₁ d}, Pell.IsFundamental a → 0 < Pell.Solution₁.x a
name: Pell.IsFundamental.x_pos
docString: A fundamental solution has positive `x`.

If a solution has `x > 1`, then `d` is positive.

type: ∀ {d : ℤ} {a : Pell.Solution₁ d}, 1 < Pell.Solution₁.x a → 0 < d
name: Pell.Solution₁.d_pos_of_one_lt_x
docString: If a solution has `x > 1`, then `d` is positive.

Nonzero divisors have nonzero valuation.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] [inst_2 : IsDedekindDomain R]
  (v : IsDedekindDomain.HeightOneSpectrum R) (x : ↥(nonZeroDivisors R)),
  IsDedekindDomain.HeightOneSpectrum.intValuationDef v ↑x ≠ 0
name: IsDedekindDomain.HeightOneSpectrum.int_valuation_ne_zero'
docString: Nonzero divisors have nonzero valuation.

Pointwise, the multiplicative indicators of δ-thickenings of a set eventually coincide
with the multiplicative indicator of the set as δ>0 tends to zero.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : PseudoEMetricSpace α] {β : Type u_2} [inst_1 : One β] (f : α → β) (E : Set α) (x : α),
  ∀ᶠ (δ : ℝ) in nhdsWithin 0 (Set.Ioi 0),
    Set.mulIndicator (Metric.thickening δ E) f x = Set.mulIndicator (closure E) f x
name: mulIndicator_thickening_eventually_eq_mulIndicator_closure
docString:
Pointwise, the multiplicative indicators of δ-thickenings of a set eventually coincide
with the multiplicative indicator of the set as δ>0 tends to zero.
